catalyst.source: Vacancy defects in the porous ZnO nanoplates facilitate separation of charge carriers, and are in favor of adsorption and activation of CO2, resulting in greatly enhanced photocatalytic activity.
catalyst.context: Vacancy defects in the porous ZnO nanoplates facilitate separation of charge carriers, and are in favor of adsorption and activation of CO2, resulting in greatly enhanced photocatalytic activity. Highlights Porous ZnO nanoplates with VO defects are prepared by annealing precursor in air. Amount of vacancy defects in ZnO can be tailored by changing heating temperature. Different amount of defects lead to different performance for CO2 photoreduction. VO defect can facilitate the separation of photogenerated electrons and holes. VO defect is in favor of the adsorption and activation of CO2 on ZnO surface.

catalyst.context: All the chemicals were analytical reagent and were used without any further purification.Zinc powder (AR) and ethylenediamine ( 99) were bought from Shanghai Aladdin Biological Technology Co., Ltd.Sulfur powder and absolute ethanol ( 99.7) were purchased from Beijing Chemical Works.The pure water used in the experiment was acquired by a Milli-Q Plus system (Millipore, France) with 18.2 Mcm resistivity. ZnS(en)0.5 precursor was synthesized via a solvothermal route in the presence of ethylenediamine (en) as solvent and structure-directing agent according to the protocol reported previously 29.In a typical process, 1 mmol of Zn powder and 3 mmol of S powder were dissolved in 90 mL of ethylenediamine under constant stirring for half an hour.Subsequently, the mixture was transferred into an autoclave, which was then put into a furnace and maintained at 180 oC for 24 h.After the autoclave cooled naturally down to room temperature in air, the resultant white precipitate was separated by centrifugation, washed with ethanol and pure water for several times to remove the organic residual, and finally dried overnight in vacuum oven at 65 oC. The porous ZnO nanoplates were prepared based on the previous report with minor modification 30.Typically, the porous ZnO nanoplates with defects were achieved by annealing the as-synthesized ZnS(en)0.5 precursor at different temperature (600, 650 and 700 oC) for 2 h in air, which were denoted as ZnO-600, ZnO-650 and ZnO-700, respectively. Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was conducted with a flow rate of 200 mLmin 1 and a heating rate of 10 oC min 1 in air using Diamond TG/DTA thermal analyzer.Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) absorption spectra were collected on a Perkin Elmer spectrometer from 4500 to 500 cm -1 .The crystal structure of obtained samples was identified from 20o to 80o at a scan rate of 0.1 second per step by X-ray diffraction (XRD) using Bruker D8 focus diffractometer with Cu-K radiation.The surface morphology and lattice structure of the synthesized samples were visualized by using Hitachi S4800 FESEM and Tecnai G2 F20 U-TWIN transmission electron microscopy (TEM).Specific surface area and CO2 adsorption isotherms were measured by a surface area and porosity analyzer (Micromeritics, TriStar II 3020).UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra were collected by Lambda 750 UV/Vis/NIR spectrophotometer using BaSO4 as the background.Valence band position of the samples was determined from Xray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) using ESCALAB 250Xi X-ray photoelectron spectrometer.Raman spectra were recorded by using Raman spectrometer (Renishaw inVia plus) with the 514 nm laser.Time-resolved photoluminescence (PL) spectra were recorded on spectrometer (FLS920, Edinburgh Instruments) with 375 nm excitation. Transient photocurrent measurement was carried out on an electrochemical station (Zahner, Germany).Mott-Schottky curves were measured on a CHI 660D electrochemical station (Shanghai Chenhua, China).The 0.35 M Na2SO4 was used as the electrolyte.A standard three-electrode system was used for the photoelectrochemical tests, i.e., the electrode coated by the obtained sample was used as the working electrode, a platinum plate as the counter electrode, and a saturated calomel electrode (SCE) as the reference electrode.The photocurrent was measured at a bias voltage of 0.6 V with light on and off every 15 seconds.The working electrode was prepared as follows, 10 mg of the as-prepared photocatalyst was dispersed ultrasonically for 1 h in 1 mL of ethanol.The resultant suspension (200 uL) was dropped on the FTO glass substrate with 1.8 cm 2 area and dried at 70 oC for 6 h in the vacuum oven. The photoreduction of CO2 was conducted in a quartz reactor illuminated by UV-vis light with a 300 W Xe lamp (PLS-SXE300) under constant stirring.For the photocatalytic measurements, pure CO2 was first bubbled into 100 mL of solution containing 0.25 M Na2SO3 and 1 M NaOH for at least 30 min.Then 30 mg of ZnO powder was suspended in the above solution under sonication for 30 min, followed by being bubbled with pure compressed CO2 ( 99.999) for another 30 min in the dark to reach the balance of CO2 adsorption-desorption before illumination.The products were collected every 30 min and analyzed online by gas chromatograph (Agilent 7890A) equipped with flame ionization detector (FID) and thermal conductivity detector (TCD). For the adsorption of CO2 on ZnO surface, density functional theory (DFT) calculations were carried out using the DMol 3 code 31,32.The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with the Perdew, Burke and Ernzerhof (PBE) functional 33 was utilized for all geometric optimization and single-point energy calculations.Double-numerical quality and additional polarization functions (DND) were employed as the basis sets.The convergence criteria for structure optimization was set to energy tolerance of 1.010 -5 Ha per atom, maximum force tolerance of 2.0 10 -3 Ha/A, and maximum displacement tolerance of 5.010 -3 A.The ZnO (110) surface was modeled as a (22) rectangular surface slab with four O-Zn-O layers.A vacuum region of 15 A in the z-direction is used to avoid the slab-slab interactions.The bottom two layers in this slab were frozen, whereas the rest of the layers are allowed to relax.A Monkhorst-Pack mesh with the 661 k-point grid was used to sample the Brillouin zone for the surfaces.The adsorption energy is defined as EAds ETotal ESurf EMol, where ETotal is the total energy of the system containing substrate and molecule, ESurf is the energy of optimized clean surface, and EMol is the energy of the isolated molecule.

catalyst.context: In conclusion, the porous ZnO nanoplates with vacancy defects have been prepared by annealing the ZnS(en)0.5precursor in air.The amount of defects in the obtained samples decreases with the increase of annealing temperature.It is found that the defects can serve as separation centers to facilitate the separation of photogenerated electrons and holes.Moreover, the defects are also in favor of the adsorption and activation of CO2 on the ZnO surface.Thus, the ZnO-600 sample has the highest separation efficiency and CO2 activation, and the largest CO2 adsorption capacity as well; followed by ZnO-650, and ZnO-700 is the lowest for all these.Accordingly, ZnO-600 shows the highest photocatalytic activity for CO2 reduction, while ZnO-700 exhibits the lowest activity.However, it is noted that many different types of defects may exist in the catalysts and, thereby, the suitable advanced techniques are required to detect them and probe the individual influence of each defect on the photocatalytic performance.In addition, Zn5(OH)6(CO3)2 is observed during the CO2 reduction (Fig. S6), indicating that ZnO is not very stable being a photocatalyst.However, it is reported the Zn5(OH)6(CO3)2 can be the active intermediate species for CO2 photoreduction and the defects in ZnO can promote its formation through the Lewis acid-base interaction 43.Thus, further study is desirable to improve the stability of the photocatalyst and, meanwhile, still exhibit high photoactivity. light source.context: Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was carried out to study the thermal decomposition process of the ZnS(en)0.5precursor in order to obtain the proper thermal treatment temperature in our study (Fig. S1a).Pure ZnO samples can be prepared by annealing ZnS(en)0.5 at 600 oC (i.e., ZnO-600) for 2 h.For comparison, ZnO-650 and ZnO-700 were also prepared just by changing the annealing temperature, while keeping other conditions unchanged.Fig. 1 shows that the typical XRD pattern of ZnS(en)0.5 agrees well with previous work 29,343536.Clearly, all the annealed samples display a similar XRD pattern, for which all the diffraction peaks are well ascribed to the standard Wurtzite ZnO (JCPDS no. .No any other impurity peaks are observed in the samples obtained after thermal treatment, indicating complete transformation of the precursor to ZnO, which is further supported by FT-IR analysis (Fig. S1b).In addition, the particle size can be calculated by using the XRD data in terms of Scherrer equation D K/cos, where D is the crystal size, k 0.89, is the wavelength of X-ray with a value of 0.1542 nm, is the FWHM, and is the diffraction angle.Thus, the size of the obtained ZnO-600, ZnO-650 and ZnO-700 is calculated to be around 13, 18 and 22 nm, respectively.Such increase in the crystal size is consistent with the decrease in the BET specific surface area, which is respectively determined to be 17.96, 10.89 and 9.50 m 2 /g for ZnO-600, ZnO-650 and ZnO-700 using the typical N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm of the as-synthesized porous ZnO nanoplates (Fig. S2).Furthermore, FWHM value of the diffraction peaks becomes smaller (i.e., the peak becomes sharper) with increase of annealing temperature, indicating the increase of the crystallinity. SEM images of the as-synthesized ZnO samples are shown in Fig. 2. Plate-like morphology with porous structures are clearly observed.Obviously, the porosity of the samples decreases with the increase of annealing temperature.TEM images also indicate the formation of porous nanoplate morphology (Fig. 3 and Fig. S3).Moreover, a clear inter-planar spacing of 0.28 and 0.26 nm is observed in all the obtained ZnO samples from the HRTEM images, which is well indexed respectively to the d-spacing of (002) and (100) lattice planes of the Wurtzite ZnO.The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern with a bright diffraction spots indicates good single crystalline characteristic of the obtained porous ZnO nanoplates.The corresponding elemental mapping images of Zn and O of the ZnO-600 sample are also shown in Fig. 3, and those of ZnO-650 and ZnO-700 are given in Fig. S4.Clearly, the Zn and O elements are homogeneously distributed in the whole nanoplates for all the obtained ZnO samples. Photocatalytic reduction of CO2 in water under white light irradiation is performed to evaluate the activity of the obtained porous ZnO nanoplates.The main photoreduction product over all the obtained ZnO samples is CO.Blank experiments are also conducted (i.e., without CO2, illumination or photocatalysts), no any photoreduction products like CH4 or CO can be observed, confirming that the observed CO is indeed from CO2 photoreduction.Fig. 4 shows the CO production as a function of illumination time.Obviously, the amount of CO increases as the illumination time prolongs for all the samples.The production yield of CO is 3.8, 3.1 and 2.5 mol/g for the catalyst of ZnO-600, ZnO-650 and ZnO-700, respectively.Thus, the ZnO-600 sample has the highest activity for CO2 photoreduction, followed by ZnO-650, and ZnO-700 shows the lowest activity.Transient photocurrent response results further confirm such a sequence in activity, i.e., the ZnO-600 sample has the largest photocurrent density under the same measurement conditions, followed by ZnO-650, and ZnO-700 is the lowest (Fig. 4b).Moreover, the photocurrent increases sharply once upon the samples are subject to the light illumination, while it decreases immediately when the light is switched off.This indicates the observed photocurrent response is indeed caused by the CO2 photoreduction. The first considered factors that may have an impact on the photoreduction activity are the light harvesting and conduction band (CB) potential, which are highly dependent on the alignment of energy levels of a photocatalyst.So UV-visible light absorption spectra of the obtained porous ZnO nanoplates are collected (Fig. 5) so as to determine the bandgap (Eg) based on the Kubelka-Munk method using Tauc plots derived from the corresponding absorption spectra (insets of Fig. 5).The obtained value of Eg for ZnO-600, ZnO-650 and ZnO-700 is 3.21, 3.24 and 3.25 eV, respectively.To determine the CB potential, the valence band maximum (VB) is first measured using XPS valence band spectra (Fig. 6a), which is about 2.87 eV for all the obtained ZnO samples.Given the work function of the XPS instrument used in this work is 4.62 eV and 0 V (vs SHE) corresponds to 4.60 eV (vs vacuum level), the CB potential for ZnO-600, ZnO-650 and ZnO-700 can thus be calculated to be 0.32,0.35 and 0.36 V (vs SHE), respectively.In addition, the flat band potential can be determined using the Mott-Schottky curves (Fig. 6b), which is 0.57, 0.54 and 0.55 V (vs SCE) for ZnO-600, ZnO-650 and ZnO-700, respectively.Therefore, the difference in the alignment of energy levels among all the obtained ZnO samples (specifically, the potential of CB and flat band, as well as Eg) is very small.Accordingly, another factor, here the defects in the nanocatalysts as discussed below, is suggested to play a major role in the observed different photoreduction activity. Chemical composition and atomic stoichiometry of the obtained ZnO samples are studied by energy dispersive X-ray diffraction (EDX), which are listed in Table S1.Obviously, both Zn and O exist in the porous ZnO nanoplates, which is further confirmed by the XPS survey spectra (Fig. S5).It is found that the respective atomic ratio of O/Zn from TEM-EDX analysis for ZnO-600, ZnO-650 and ZnO-700 is 0.65, 0.77 and 0.97, indicating that all the obtained samples are oxygen deficient.Although it is highly possible that many different types of defects related to oxygen deficiency can be present in the samples, here oxygen vacancy (VO) is used as a typical representative.So the amount of VO in ZnO decreases with the increase of the annealing temperature, which is further confirmed by Raman results (Fig. 7).Two strong peaks at 99 and 437 cm -1 are the characteristic Raman signals of Wurtzite ZnO and can be identified as the vibration mode of nonpolar optical phonons 37.Another strong peak at 590 cm -1 is ascribed to the contribution of VO 38,39.The ratio of peak intensity I590/I437 can thus be used to represent the change in the amount of VO, which decreases with increase of annealing temperature, consistent with the EDX results.Based on the aforementioned discussion, the observed difference in the photoreduction activity for all the samples can thus be elucidated.It is generally believed that the adsorption and activation of CO2 that can strongly affect the reaction pathway and dynamics 24,25 are the first essential steps to initiate the subsequent photoreduction reactions, which are highly dependent on the vacancy defects of the photocatalyst surface.For this concern, the adsorption isotherms are carried out to investigate the CO2 adsorption property of the samples (Fig. 8a).It is found that the ZnO-600 sample has the largest CO2 adsorption capacity under the same pressure, followed by ZnO-650, and ZnO-700 is the lowest.DFT calculation is used to calculate the adsorption energy (EAds) so as to further study the influence of defects on the adsorption behavior of CO2 onto the clean surface and VO defect on ZnO surface.Each adsorbed structure is optimized and the most energetically favorable configuration is shown in Fig. 8b.The corresponding adsorption energy is calculated to be 0.55 and 0.60 eV for the CO2 adsorption energy on the clean surface and VO defect on ZnO surface, respectively (Table S2).The more negative value of EAds, the stronger the adsorption is.So the defect can facilitate the CO2 adsorption compared to the perfect surface.This explains well why the CO2 adsorption capacity on ZnO decreases with the increase of annealing temperature, resulting in the decreased activity for CO2 photoreduction. As for the activation of CO2, it is known that huge amount of energy is required to change the CO2 molecule from linear to bent.Thus, the activation energy may be dropped down to some degree if the configuration of a linear CO2 molecule (i.e., bond angle and length) can be distorted upon adsorption.Compared with the experimental value of 180 for the bond angle of a free CO2 molecule, it changes respectively to 176.5 and 174.7 according to the DFT calculation when CO2 is adsorbed on the clean surface and VO defect (Table S2).Meanwhile, the bond length of the two chemical bonds in CO2 becomes asymmetric, i.e., changes from 0.1176/0.1176nm to 0.1175/0.1178and 0.1171/0.1182nm for the clean surface and VO defect on ZnO surface, respectively.Thus, the distortion of CO2 configuration occurs upon adsorption on the surface, and the distortion degree for that on the VO defect is larger than that on the clean surface.In other words, the adsorption onto a surface is in favor of the CO2 activation, and the presence of defects can further facilitate the activation compared to the clean surface, leading to the improved photoreduction activity.In addition, it is known that the defects can have an impact on the separation of photogenerated charge carriers and, thereby, on the photocatalytic activity of the semiconductor catalysts.It can be concluded from Fig. 4b that the ZnO-600 sample has the highest efficiency for charge separation, followed by ZnO-650, and ZnO-700 is the lowest.This is further confirmed by the time-resolved PL results (Fig. 9).It is found that all the samples display exponential decay and can be fitted by the tri-exponential decay kinetics.The lifetime is composed of three different processes, non-radiative process (1), radiative process (2) and energy transfer process (3) 404142.Obviously, the values of PL lifetime for all these three processes decrease with the increase of annealing temperature (Table S3).This is because the defects can serve as the separation centers of charge carriers.As discussed above, the amount of VO defects decreases with increase of annealing temperature.So the ZnO-600 sample has the highest separation efficiency of charge carriers, followed by ZnO-650, and ZnO-700 exhibits the lowest separation efficiency, giving rise the enhanced photocatalytic activity for CO2 reduction.

Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was conducted with a flow rate of 200 mLmin 1 and a heating rate of 10 oC min 1 in air using Diamond TG/DTA thermal analyzer.Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) absorption spectra were collected on a Perkin Elmer spectrometer from 4500 to 500 cm -1 .The crystal structure of obtained samples was identified from 20o to 80o at a scan rate of 0.1 second per step by X-ray diffraction (XRD) using Bruker D8 focus diffractometer with Cu-K radiation.The surface morphology and lattice structure of the synthesized samples were visualized by using Hitachi S4800 FESEM and Tecnai G2 F20 U-TWIN transmission electron microscopy (TEM).Specific surface area and CO2 adsorption isotherms were measured by a surface area and porosity analyzer (Micromeritics, TriStar II 3020).UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra were collected by Lambda 750 UV/Vis/NIR spectrophotometer using BaSO4 as the background.Valence band position of the samples was determined from Xray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) using ESCALAB 250Xi X-ray photoelectron spectrometer.Raman spectra were recorded by using Raman spectrometer (Renishaw inVia plus) with the 514 nm laser.Time-resolved photoluminescence (PL) spectra were recorded on spectrometer (FLS920, Edinburgh Instruments) with 375 nm excitation. Transient photocurrent measurement was carried out on an electrochemical station (Zahner, Germany).Mott-Schottky curves were measured on a CHI 660D electrochemical station (Shanghai Chenhua, China).The 0.35 M Na2SO4 was used as the electrolyte.A standard three-electrode system was used for the photoelectrochemical tests, i.e., the electrode coated by the obtained sample was used as the working electrode, a platinum plate as the counter electrode, and a saturated calomel electrode (SCE) as the reference electrode.The photocurrent was measured at a bias voltage of 0.6 V with light on and off every 15 seconds.The working electrode was prepared as follows, 10 mg of the as-prepared photocatalyst was dispersed ultrasonically for 1 h in 1 mL of ethanol.The resultant suspension (200 uL) was dropped on the FTO glass substrate with 1.8 cm 2 area and dried at 70 oC for 6 h in the vacuum oven. The photoreduction of CO2 was conducted in a quartz reactor illuminated by UV-vis light with a 300 W Xe lamp (PLS-SXE300) under constant stirring.For the photocatalytic measurements, pure CO2 was first bubbled into 100 mL of solution containing 0.25 M Na2SO3 and 1 M NaOH for at least 30 min.Then 30 mg of ZnO powder was suspended in the above solution under sonication for 30 min, followed by being bubbled with pure compressed CO2 ( 99.999) for another 30 min in the dark to reach the balance of CO2 adsorption-desorption before illumination.The products were collected every 30 min and analyzed online by gas chromatograph (Agilent 7890A) equipped with flame ionization detector (FID) and thermal conductivity detector (TCD). For the adsorption of CO2 on ZnO surface, density functional theory (DFT) calculations were carried out using the DMol 3 code 31,32.The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with the Perdew, Burke and Ernzerhof (PBE) functional 33 was utilized for all geometric optimization and single-point energy calculations.Double-numerical quality and additional polarization functions (DND) were employed as the basis sets.The convergence criteria for structure optimization was set to energy tolerance of 1.010 -5 Ha per atom, maximum force tolerance of 2.0 10 -3 Ha/A, and maximum displacement tolerance of 5.010 -3 A.The ZnO (110) surface was modeled as a (22) rectangular surface slab with four O-Zn-O layers.A vacuum region of 15 A in the z-direction is used to avoid the slab-slab interactions.The bottom two layers in this slab were frozen, whereas the rest of the layers are allowed to relax.A Monkhorst-Pack mesh with the 661 k-point grid was used to sample the Brillouin zone for the surfaces.The adsorption energy is defined as EAds ETotal ESurf EMol, where ETotal is the total energy of the system containing substrate and molecule, ESurf is the energy of optimized clean surface, and EMol is the energy of the isolated molecule.
